title: Part One
text:
Part One is a reference for trainees preparing for the CICM and ANZCA Primary Exams.

Part One is:

Designed to cover the assessed sections of the CICM and ANZCA curricula in enough detail to pass
A rough guide for the expected depth of knowledge required on a topic
A tool to correct your written answers
A source of information you might find difficult to find elsewhere


Part One is not:

A textbook

The definitive guide to the primary exam
A complete reference
There will be both omissions and errors. If you find any, please let me know.

title: Bayesian Trial Evaluation
text:
Input the trial data into the contingency table and select whether or not the results were found significant.
Next, set the pre-test probability based on your own prior, or leave it at 0.5 if you have equipoise.
If necessary, adjust the Bayesian analysis strategy based on the characteristics of the trial.

Best Guesses and Wordle





Optimising the opening gambit in Worldle, using R.






Jan 27, 2022






No matching items

title: Best Guesses and Wordle
text:
Like much of the internet, I have been fascinated with the game Wordle. For those unaware, the basic premise is to guess a five letter word in less than six attempts. Unlike many such games, there is no initial clue. Your first guess is made blind, and then refined in subsequent rounds based on whether the letter was:
It’s a simple mechanic, and quite fun. Part of the appeal comes from the fact that it’s really a logic game. Since the potential solution space becomes very small very quickly; intelligent early guesses can remove vast swathes of dictionary from consideration. So the key question is; what are the best words to guess first?

title: Best Guesses and Wordle
text:
4. Combinations
Lastly, we take our list of best words, cross them to make a list of all possible combinations, and then cut that list down to a combination that contains only one of each of the high-yield letters, in a high-yield position.

best_combinations = list(first = best_words$word,
               second = best_words$word) %>%
  cross() %>%
  map_df(as_tibble) %>%
  mutate(word = paste(first, second, sep = ""),
         a = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "a"),
         e = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "e"),
         i = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "i"),
         l = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "l"),
         n = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "n"),
         o = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "o"),
         r = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "r"),
         s = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "s"),
         t = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "t"),
         u = stri_count_fixed(word, pattern = "u")) %>%
  filter(across(-c(first, second, word), ~ . == 1)) %>%
  select(first, second)

Warning: `cross()` was deprecated in purrr 1.0.0.
ℹ Please use `tidyr::expand_grid()` instead.
ℹ See <https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr/issues/768>.


Warning: Using `across()` in `filter()` was deprecated in dplyr 1.0.8.
ℹ Please use `if_any()` or `if_all()` instead.

knitr::kable(best_combinations,
             col.names = c("First Word", "Second Word"))



First Word
Second Word



tails
rouen


rouen
tails





There we have it! An unlikely combination.

title: cjdbarlow.github.io
text:
Anaesthetic and Intensive Care registrar fellow currently living and working in Auckland, New Zealand. I like everything at the pointy end of medicine, as well as physical computing, biotech, education, statistics, and data visualisation.
I like doing things, so please feel free to contact me about projects, ideas, or hairbrained schemes that are: medical (cardiac ++, trauma +), humanitarian, challenging (but tractable), electronic, adventurous (low predicted mortality preferred), educational, stats (prediction modelling, Bayesian, and data visualisation); or any combination of the above.

title: Bedside Scientist
text:
These are my notes built up over my anaesthetic and intensive care training, and serves as an easily-searchable personal reference when I am on the floor. As the goal is to provide guidance in uncertainty, it tends to be highly opinionated - irrespective of the level of evidence supporting those opinions. Reasonable people may disagree.
Unlike Part One, which is (or at least, was) “complete”, this is still very much under construction. Many core topics are absent, others will be covered only partially and sometimes incorrectly, particularly if it is a topic I stumbled upon years ago and have not dusted off since.
In particular (and somewhat counter-intuitively), things I know quite well are often covered poorly (if at all), and may reflect the incomplete or incorrect understanding I held when I first came across them. Conversely, topics I can claim only a passing association or interest with may be covered in unrestrained detail as I need to refresh heavily each time they arise.
It can be viewed here.
